intro: Acaena dimorphoglochin, commonly known as the variable burr bush, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves and spiny, glochidiate bracts. The plant produces small, pinkish-white flowers that are clustered in racemes. Its fruits are dry, schizocarpic achenes surrounded by persistent, barbed bracts that aid in seed dispersal. Acaena dimorphoglochin is often found in coastal and subalpine habitats, thriving in well-drained soils.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena dimorphoglochin is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in various regions across the country, including the South Island and parts of the North Island. Its distribution is largely restricted to specific ecological niches within New Zealand's diverse landscapes.
